card.title: Air New Zealand pulls the plug on 2030 climate targets
card.description: The airline says the new aircraft and alternative jet fuels are hard to get and are expensive, and it will work on a new target.

descendants.content: @joncounts It was getting too obvious that there just isn't enough suitable biomass to make meaningful amounts of jet fuel, and building the manufacturing infrastructure needed in itself by 2030 is a pure pipe dream. The answer is airships. Despite their limitations they're more practical than telling the world to just stop flying. @isaacfreeman

descendants.content: @lightweight They're not as tolerant of it as jets. But there are some things in their favour that help a bit: They don't need much in the way of sophisticated new infrastructure. They don't fly so high, avoiding the really high speed stuff, and the zone they do fly in is relatively well monitored and forecast. So ideal? No. But we're running out of options here, and *not* having rapid intercontinental transport has an impact on the carbon budget all of its own. @joncounts @isaacfreeman

descendants.content:
@lightweight @vik @joncounts @isaacfreeman
They don't handle rapid temperature changes very well... There is a balancing act between temp/press/vol of the gas bags inside.

The Hindenburg just went 'bang' but the R101 suffered the unfortunate fate of the front of it not being as waterproof as the back when it ran into a rainstorm... The front bags cooled down quickly and lost lift that couldn't be corrected with what they had left so it just nosedived into the ground... And then went 'bang'

account.note: Generally useful. Can occasionally correctly reassemble an item that may or may not have been broken initially. Appreciates Open Source but can't code for toffee.

descendants.content:
@lightweight @vik @joncounts @isaacfreeman
Nothing insurmountable, as Vik points out, but not a world saviour either.

Just gets back to the fact that, as a species, we really just DGAF about a lot of these things.

Climate change? DGAF
Proprietary vs. Open Source? DGAF
Uber being little shits? DGAF
AirBnB destroying the rental market? DGAF
Bitcoin/AI wasting resource? DGAF
All the above being paid for by future debt? DGAF

We are the epitome of self centered little arseholes and we DGAF!

@carl_klitscher This is a collective action problem. We do all care a bit, but individually we can do practically nothing, so nothing gets done.

Representative government is a tool for solving this problem, which is why we need to defend it against the rich.

descendants.content:
@carl_klitscher
I have a slightly different backstory on the R101 inquiry results: The nose seems to be the culprit, splitting inn some way. This exposed the forward bags to the airstream causing them to fail. Differences in lift at the ends could be controlled by fore and aft ballast release, but this is subject to a limit :)
@lightweight @joncounts @isaacfreeman

descendants.content:
@vik @lightweight @joncounts @isaacfreeman
I got my info from a 'Britains Greatest Machines' doco...
But yeah, essentially a problem at the front causing a significant lift differential that couldn't be corrected in time to prevent 'a loss of separation' (what the rest of us call a crash!)

Better technology, faster gas transfer capability, better ballast control, some automation etc. means I wouldn't be averse to flying in them today.

But, as you point out, at what cost?

media_attachments.description:
A screenshot from an Air New Zealand webpage on their now scrapped 2030 emissions targets, from the Internet Archive Wayback Machine, from 27 June 2024. 

Here's some of what it says (all the text doesn't fit into the Alt-text).

Why set a science-based target validated by the Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi)?

Science-based targets validated by the SBTi show companies how much and how quickly they need to reduce their greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions to prevent the worst effects of climate change. 

Getting the target validated by the SBTi was a rigorous process whereby Air New Zealand’s GHG emissions were reviewed in detail by the SBTi to ensure an accurate emissions baseline was identified and a science-based target was set.

Science-based targets are targets aligned to the commitments made by world governments in 2015 through the Paris Agreement to limit global temperature rise to well-below 2°C above pre-industrial levels and pursue efforts to limit warming to 1.5°C. 

Air New Zealand will continue to engage with the SBTi on this methodology and will evaluate the 1.5°C pathway once it is released.  The globally recognised and consistent scientific approach to setting a science-based target allows progress on carbon reductions to be compared with other companies’ decarbonisation efforts. Over 1,500 companies are leading the transition to a net zero economy by setting emissions reduction targets validated by the SBTi.

card.title: 2030 Science Based Target
card.description: Flight NZ0™ is our most important journey yet. It’s our commitment to net zero carbon emissions by 2050.

descendants.content: @isaacfreeman @joncounts Polluters should be required to pay additional tax at least equivalent to the costs of buying overseas CCs. Fresh, healthy air is better for cows (and other livestock) too.
